newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Southeast power mixed ahead of milder weather.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Southeast power mixed ahead of milder weather.

text.p: Spot bulk electricity prices in the southeastern U.S. were mixed Wednesday, stalled by sluggish activity amid forecasts for above-normal temperatures through the end of the week and a return of some nuclear power, sources said.

Firm, peak power prices in the northern part of the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) territory for Wednesday delivery were talked in the $21.00-22.00 per megawatt hour (MWh) range, down about $1 from Monday's trading range.
Late deals into TVA were reported done as low as $15.50 and $16.00.
TVA's 1,148 megawatt (MW) Sequoyah 2 nuclear unit in Soddy-Daisy, Tenn., returned to full power early Tuesday.
Firm, off-peak electricity in northern TVA was assessed around $14.50, mostly unchanged from Monday.

At the Georgia/Florida border, prices for firm, peak electricity in 16 hour blocks for Wednesday delivery were quoted in the $22.50-$24.80 per MWh range, with the bulk of business done around $23.50-24.00.
These prices compare with Monday's market in the $22.00-23.00 per MWh area.
Firm, off-peak power for Wednesday at the Ga./Fla. border was notionally assessed at $16.00-16.50.
Temperatures in the Southeast are expected to warm to above-normal levels on Wednesday and Thursday but then return to more seasonable levels this weekend.
Separately, Duke Power's 1,129 MW Catawba nuclear power unit in Clover, S.C., was operating at full power Tuesday.
